message: Anyone seeking assistance with a federal agency, including those suffering with issues resulting from Hurricane Irma, are invited to meet with a member of my staff and the staff of Senator Bill Nelson during the following joint office hours tomorrow (September 19, 2017):  10:00 a.m. – 12:00 p.m. at the Zephyrhills Public Library                (5347 8th Street, Zephyrhills, FL  33542)                                       and 2:00 p.m. – 4:00 p.m. at the United Way of Pasco           (17230 Camelot Ct.  Land O’ Lakes, FL  34638)  Please contact 727-232-2921 for additional information.
May 2017 be filled with happiness and good health. Happy New Year!

I opposed the measure to change the Office of Congressional Ethics from the very beginning, and I am glad to see that it will not have a place in the 115th Congress. I am confident that this House will continue to hold Members to the highest ethical standards, fully accountable to the people. The public’s trust must never be taken for granted.

It is a privilege to be sworn into the 115th Congress today! Your voices will continue to guide me as your representative in the People’s House, and I pledge to keep working hard to solve problems here at home in Florida and across the country.

One of my top priorities this year will continue to be improving care for our nation’s Veterans. In fact, the very first legislation of 2017 passed by the House will help fix problems and increase transparency at the VA. The Ensuring VA Accountability Act would require the VA to maintain thorough, complete records of employee performance, holding those who care for our Veterans accountable.
Today, I gave my first speech of the 115th Congress to outline my vision for reforming the VA and improving care for Veterans.

The men and women who dedicated their lives to serving our nation should be compensated fairly for their sacrifices. That’s why the first bill I introduced in the 115th Congress is the Retired Pay Restoration Act, which will ensure that all Veterans who receive retirement payments following their military service can also receive disability payments from the VA. With this bill, we’re making sure Veterans are getting the benefits they have earned and deserve.

Now is the time to rebuild our relationship with Israel, and signal to her and the rest of the world where America stands. Last month, the United Nations, with the blessing of the Obama Administration, single-handedly damaged the US’s longstanding relationship with our best and only democratic ally in the Middle East. That is not who we are as a country, and that is not the direction we want to go. I am proud the House today demonstrated overwhelming bipartisan support for condemning these anti-Israel actions.

Today I’m thinking of my friends celebrating in Tarpon Springs at the largest Epiphany celebration in the Western Hemisphere. Although I’m in Washington, D.C. fulfilling my legislative duties, I hope to be with you all next year.  Xronia Polla!
My prayers are with the #FLL victims and their families after today’s shooting. Thank you to the first responders for your courage.
As the 115th Congress kicks off, please know that my staff and I are ready to work for you! Call my office in D.C. at 202-225-5755 or in Florida at 727-232-2921 if we can ever be of assistance.

Seven blue lights on my windowsill representing the five Florida law enforcement officers we lost in the past year, as well as Orlando Police Officer Master Sgt. Debra Clayton who was gunned down this morning and Tarpon Springs Police Officer Charles “Charlie” Kondek whose end of watch was December 21, 2014. For National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, join me in thanking those who serve and protect our communities. We must never forget their sacrifices.

Families across Florida are feeling the burden of Obamacare. Premiums have skyrocketed an average of 19% in our state, and insurers are fleeing the market left and right. In fact, 73% of counties in Florida only have one insurance provider, leaving people with higher costs and less choice when it comes to their health care. House Republicans are offering solid solutions to make our nation’s health care system work for everyone, without pulling the rug out from anybody’s feet. We’re focused on a more affordable, more personalized health care plan that empowers patients, not Washington.

Human trafficking isn’t only happening in other countries, we’ve seen it right here in Pasco County. January is Human Trafficking Awareness Month, and I’m thinking of the millions of men, women, and children—the most vulnerable among us—exploited by human traffickers. We must continue the fight to end human trafficking and restore people their fundamental rights.

I’m honored to have the chance to serve as Vice Chairman of the House VA Committee. With over 70,000 Veterans in my district, and two major VA hospitals, I am dedicated to standing up for the men and women who have worn our nation’s uniform. I look forward to working with Chairman Dr. Phil Roe and my colleagues to improve care for Veterans, and bring much needed accountability and reform to the VA. If you or a loved one are experiencing problems dealing with the VA, please call my office at 727-232-2921.

I spoke on the House floor today about my legislation to make sure first responders have a stockpile of medical kits, protective gear, ventilators, and more in the event of an emergency. During a crisis like a terrorist attack or major hurricane, our first responders bravely risk their lives on behalf of our safety. I introduced this bill to protect the public, and “protect our protectors.”
One week out from Inauguration Day! I’m looking forward to welcoming constituents from Florida’s 12th District to the nation’s capital for the ceremonies.

I’m very pleased the VA announced it would publish the rule to expand benefits to all Veterans who were exposed to contaminated water at Camp Lejeune. I have long advocated for this rule, and authored legislation to help make it happen. Those Veterans already gave so much on behalf of our nation, it was not right they had to sacrifice their overall health, too. Finally, the men and women who served at Camp Lejeune will have better access to the benefits they need and have earned.
Celebrating Russian Orthodox New Year with good friend, John Catsimatidis.
Enjoyed spending this evening with my good friends of AIPAC, including Brian Taub,  at the annual Tampa event. My simple bipartisan message was loud and clear: the US-ISRAEL bond is unshakeable!

Today we honor the life of a great man and a pioneer of justice, Martin Luther King, Jr. We remember his call for America to live up to its promises of freedom and equality for all. May his legacy live on.

231 years ago today in 1786, the Virginia General Assembly adopted Thomas Jefferson’s Statue for Religious Freedom, the landmark clause which later became the basis for our First Amendment rights. On National Religious Freedom Day, let us join together in honor of one of the fundamental principles our great nation was founded upon. As a member of the International Religious Freedom Caucus, and as a Greek Orthodox Christian, I will continue to promote religious liberty in our nation and around the world.
Floridians visiting Washington, D.C. for the inauguration are invited to my office for an open house tomorrow. Hope to see you there!

Thank you to the Upper Tampa Bay Chamber for inviting me to your meeting today! I’m working to make sure the government gets out of the way to allow small businesses in our community to grow and flourish.

341 Florida National Guardsmen are in Washington, D.C. this week, joining the thousands of military members from around the country to provide security assistance for the inauguration. Join me in thanking these brave men and women for all they do to keep us safe!
Very excited to welcome these Floridians to Washington, D.C. for the inaugural celebration!

Today, we witnessed the peaceful transition of power, a freedom we have been blessed with since America’s founding. Regardless of your political views, let us come together in support for our great nation and hope for a bright future. I look forward to working with the Trump Administration to strengthen our economy, keep Americans safe from threats at home and abroad, and honor our nation’s military and Veterans. God bless America today and every day in this new chapter of her history.

What a humbling moment on the eve of the inauguration. For my work in Congress, especially as it relates to religious freedom, I was presented the Medal of St. Paul, the highest honor in the Greek Orthodox Church for a lay person, by  His Eminence Archbishop Demetrios.  Congratulations to my co-honoree, friend, fellow Archon in the Greek Orthodox church, and Trump White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus. I can’t wait to work with Reince and the Trump Administration on an agenda that will make healthcare affordable, secure our borders, completely overhaul the tax code, and honor our Veterans!

As dangerous weather sweeps over the Tampa Bay area, please pay heed to local weather reports and  reach out to my office if you have any weather related emergencies.  Our local number is 727-232-2921. PLEASE STAY SAFE!

If you need assistance with a federal agency like the IRS, Social Security, or the VA, my staff will be holding office hours in Wesley Chapel this week. We will do everything we can to get you results!

What changes do you want to see in our nation’s health care system? I will be holding listening sessions on health care reform, including the repeal and replacement of Obamacare, in Pasco and Pinellas counties—and I want to hear from you!

For the last eighteen years, the Ridge Road extension project has been stuck in a quagmire of federal regulations and repetitive procedures in the Army Corps review process. That’s why I’ve sent a letter to President Trump urging him to designate the Ridge Road project as a high priority. In the case of a natural disaster, the people of Pasco County deserve an effective evacuation route to keep them safe.

Great to have these wonderful folks from Our Lady of the Rosary in Land O’ Lakes here in the nation’s capital for #MarchForLife! Floridians visiting D.C. for the event are welcome to stop by my office Rayburn 2112 for coffee and donuts this afternoon.
On #HolocaustRemembranceDay, let us keep in our hearts the over six million victims of the Holocaust and vow “Never Again.”

Too often, we’ve seen the price of potentially lifesaving drugs skyrocket as bad actors take advantage of monopolies in the market. In fact, this is one of the top issues I hear about from constituents. People in my district and across the country need more options when it comes to accessing affordable medication, and that’s exactly what our bipartisan bill, the Lower Drug Costs Through Competition Act, seeks to do. Glad to be working with my colleague Congressman Kurt Schrader on this important initiative. Our proposal uses the free market to lower drug costs, incentivize competition among drug makers, and help get treatments to patients faster.

Just four weeks into the 115th Congress, my first legislation of 2017 has unanimously passed the House: the Medical Preparedness Allowable Use Act. The legislation secures reliable grant funding for the stockpiling of medical kits and equipment for first responders across the country, ensuring our communities are prepared for any type of emergency.  When the worst occurs, our first responders are there for us on the front lines. The least we can do is make sure they have the tools to do their jobs and keep us safe.

Judge Neil Gorsuch is a steadfast conservative who has dedicated much of his life to upholding the Constitution. I applaud President Trump's decision to nominate him to the U.S.  Supreme Court, filling the seat of the great constitutional scholar, Antonin Scalia. Judge Gorsuch will serve the court and the American people well. I hope my colleagues in the U.S. Senate confirm him quickly so the court can carry on its work with a full bench.

Enjoyed meeting folks with the National Federation of the Blind yesterday! Loss of sight does not mean loss of an active, meaningful life. I will continue to be an advocate for the blind community in Congress.

What an honor to meet Lieutenant Jim Downing, the oldest known Pearl Harbor survivor at 103 years old, and thank him for his dedicated service to our country. We would not be the nation we are today without our WWII Veterans.

My view as the health subcommittee hearing is underway. We are examining reforms to keep our nation’s health care system affordable and patient-centered. Learn more here: https://energycommerce.house.gov/hearings-and-votes/hearings/patient-relief-collapsing-health-markets
Thank you to everyone who came to my health care reform listening session this morning in Pinellas County.
February is #BlackHistoryMonth. Join me in recognizing and celebrating the contributions of all African Americans who helped shape our nation’s history.
Happy Valentine's Day to my beautiful wife, Eva!

Proud to announce that the U.S. House passed important legislation this week, the WINGMAN Act, that will help congressional offices better assist Veterans dealing with issues at the VA. The problem is that when a constituent calls the office to ask about the status of a claim for benefits, the only thing we can do is contact the VA and wait for the agency to respond. I know I get very frustrated, and I’m sure my colleagues and the Veteran do as well, with how long it takes for the VA to respond. If signed into law, the WINGMAN Act provides a common sense solution, allowing congressional offices like mine to look up the status of the claim in the VA’s database, with the Veteran's permission. http://www.sunshinestatenews.com/story/ted-yohos-wingman-va-reform-proposal-passes-house
Fantastic to meet these Florida heroes from Jewish War Veterans of the U.S.A. I am deeply grateful for their service and sacrifice on behalf of our nation.

Thank you to all the constituents who joined in my telephone town hall tonight! I already held two in-person town hall meetings this month, and I'm planning another soon, but these telephone events are a great way to reach people when I'm stuck in D.C.

I heard a clear message from my constituents at recent town halls: people with pre-existing conditions need the peace of mind of knowing that they can get – and keep – health care. That’s why I co-sponsored legislation, the Pre-Existing Conditions Protection Act, to prohibit insurers from denying access, limiting coverage, or raising premiums because someone is sick, under the plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. At events in Palm Harbor and New Port Richey, I listened to folks share personal stories about themselves and loved ones who were denied access to coverage because of a chronic illness. I made a promise to gather input from the people of Florida’s 12th District about the future of our nation’s health care, and I am keeping that promise with this legislation. We will protect those with pre-existing conditions and put in place a health care system that works for everybody.

Enjoyed meeting these bright students from Dr. John Long Middle School in Wesley Chapel. They are in Washington, D.C. for Winter Congress, an annual conference for students to participate in mock government, writing, debating, and passing their own laws. Most impressive, they are the only middle school in the country in the program competing against high school students. Keep up the great work!

I would like to invite you – the people of Florida’s 12th District – to my third event this month in a series of public listening sessions on the future of our nation’s health care. As your representative, I have a duty to listen to you and gather input to bring back with me to Washington. Even if we may disagree, I believe we can still work together and find common ground.  Please see below for details.   What: Wesley Chapel Health Care Reform Listening Session  When: Wednesday, February 22, 6:00pm – 8:00pm. Where: Wesley Chapel High School Performing Arts Center, 30651 Wells Road, Wesley Chapel, FL 33545  I hope to see you there! Please call my office at 727-232-2921 with any questions.

Tomorrow, I will be hosting my 9th annual career expo and employment fair in Tarpon Springs. This event is a fantastic opportunity to connect employers with potential employees, and support job growth in our area. Job seekers of all ages, skills, and experience levels are encouraged to attend and meet with local businesses that are currently hiring.   Over 40 employers from our community will be there offering a wide range of fields, including health care, law enforcement, retail, education, and more. Don’t forget to dress professionally and bring resumes! Check my website for details.

Congratulations to Bethany from Land O’Lakes on receiving a Congressional Award for her dedication to community service and leadership. That commitment to her community will soon extend to the nation as she has accepted an appointment to attend the Naval Academy in Annapolis, Maryland based on a nomination from my office. Tremendous achievements on both counts!

Thank you to everyone who came out tonight in Wesley Chapel for my third health care town hall this month. It's my duty as a representative to listen to my constituents, whether we agree or disagree. We can find common ground and have a constructive exchange of ideas. That’s what democracy is all about! The Affordable Care Act in its current state is unsustainable and it’s only going to get worse—costs are going up, while choices and flexibility are dwindling. We need a health care system that is truly patient-focused, and I will use the input from my recent meetings to shape my work on the replacement legislation.

I greatly appreciate the companies and residents who came out yesterday and helped make this year’s job fair a success! Job seekers young and old had the opportunity to meet with over 40 local businesses that are currently hiring in a range of career fields. Our community is open for business.

At the top of the agenda during my meeting with local Veterans leaders: Improving transition assistance programs for our nation’s heroes returning home. Right now, our military spends months preparing our service members for their assignments, and yet they only spend a few days preparing them to reintegrate to civilian life. I believe we need greater collaboration with the VA, the DoD, as well as local and community initiatives to better serve our Veterans and their families.

Today we commemorate 72 years since this iconic moment—members of the United States Marines Corps raising the stars and stripes over Iwo Jima during World War II. We would not be the nation we are today without the service and sacrifice of the Greatest Generation.

After holding three public listening sessions in Pasco and Pinellas counties, I met today with local doctors, patient advocates, and health care industry experts to discuss the replacement of the Affordable Care Act. I’m grateful for their input and I look forward to returning to work in Washington packed with the ideas and suggestions of Florida’s 12th District.

I’m very glad to welcome Colin and his family from Hillsborough County to the nation’s capital! Colin’s passion for politics at such a young age is inspiring. Tomorrow night he will have a front row seat to history as my guest for President Trump’s first address to a joint session of Congress.

In honor of #RareDiseaseDay, I introduced the OPEN Act to help open the door to potentially hundreds of new treatments for rare diseases. We need to help make sure those suffering from a rare condition can find safe, effective, and affordable medication. I was inspired to write the OPEN Act after meeting with folks who live with rare diseases, like Ashleigh Pike, Candace Lerman, and Kelly Freeman from Florida. The ideas that shaped this legislation came from those who it will help most—rare disease patients. After all, rare diseases are not a rare problem.

Great to see Governor Scott and Pasco County Commissioners in Washington today. We had a productive meeting about the Ridge Road extension, a critical infrastructure improvement and public safety project.

Parkinson’s patient advocate Michael J. Fox visited the Capitol today to support research to discover new treatments, and eventually a cure, for the disease. I was glad to have the opportunity to meet with him and discuss this very important issue. With the latest investments in research, biomedical technology, and outreach awareness there is hope for the millions of patients living with Parkinson’s.

The President’s Joint Address tonight called for unity, laying out an optimistic and forward-looking vision of America. One message was clear: We can keep our promises and do right by the American people if we work together.  I look forward to working with the Administration, and my colleagues on both sides of the aisle in Congress, to improve care for our nation’s Veterans, support our men and women in uniform, secure our borders, invest in medical research, fix our infrastructure, and much more.
It's #RareDiseaseWeek and I'm speaking this morning with patients, families, and advocates about getting treatments to the 30 million people affected by rare diseases.

Wonderful to join hundreds of congenital heart disease patients, advocates, and organizations this morning. There have been great strides made in the research and treatment of CHD, but there’s much we can do to make sure babies born with CHD live longer, healthier lives. I am proud to be a partner in this fight by introducing the Congenital Heart Futures Reauthorization Act, but the real champions are CHD patients and their families.

I will be hosting my second annual Heroes Among Us event to recognize the men and women who make Florida’s 12th District such a wonderful place to live. Heroes Among Us will honor those who are dedicated to volunteerism, good deeds, and going above and beyond to serve others. If you know somebody who makes a positive difference in the community, I encourage you to nominate them. Nominations can be emailed to my staffer Tucker O’Brien at tucker.obrien@mail.house.gov. Submissions should include the nominee’s name, email address, phone number, and reasons why he or she should be recognized. The deadline for nominations is March 31, 2017. It’s time we recognize the individuals who help make our community so special!
Happy birthday, Florida! The state we call home turns 172 today. Florida was granted statehood to become the nation’s 27th state on March 3, 1845.

Community Health Centers (CHCs) in Florida and around the country do amazing work to provide quality health care to those in need. I met with the Community Health Centers of Pinellas team at their Tarpon Springs center today to discuss how we can better support CHCs.

House Republicans are keeping a critical promise to the American people by repealing and replacing the unsustainable Affordable Care Act. Most importantly, we’re delivering these reforms in an open and transparent manner. I invite you to read and share the bill text at ReadTheBill.GOP. After holding three town halls across my district plus a roundtable meeting all in recent weeks, listening to hundreds of constituents for more than a combined eight hours, I was proud to use their input and ideas in this legislation. That’s why I fought to maintain some of the ACA’s more popular provisions, like protecting patients with pre-existing conditions, eliminating lifetime caps on care, and allowing young adults to stay on their parent’s insurance until age 26. With this legislation, we will lower costs, increase options, and empower patients to make their own health care choices in a system that works for all.
Firefighters from Clearwater and Tarpon Springs were out in Washington this week. Thank you for everything you do for our communities!
Took a short break from over 24 hours of committee debate on the American Health Care Act to meet with Governor Scott this morning. I look forward to working together to solidify Medicaid in Florida.

Happy National K9 Veterans Day to the military canines who served alongside our men and women in uniform! These dogs save lives by helping sniff out IEDs and locating enemy positions.  As founder of the Congressional Humane Bond Caucus, I have worked to reunite K9 warriors and their hero handlers after their tours of duty are over.

Do you know somebody who makes a positive impact on our community? I’m honoring those who make Florida’s 12th District a special place with my second annual Heroes Among Us award. Nominate the everyday hero in your life by emailing my staff at tucker.obrien@mail.house.gov. The deadline for submissions is March 31 with an awards ceremony to follow later this spring.

This week, the House is voting on the VA Accountability First Act to bring long overdue accountability and transparency to the VA.  I'm proud to have co-sponsored this legislation to improve care for our Veterans and ensure VA employees are upholding their duty to care for those who have served.

Today we celebrate the 100th birthday of James “Maggie” Magellas, a U.S. Army officer during World War II and the most decorated officer in the history of the 82nd Airborne Division. He shared memories of his service, starting in the ROTC program and receiving his commission as a Second Lieutenant in the wake of Pearl Harbor. Join me in thanking Maggie for his service to our country, and sharing his incredible story.

Too often, the VA has failed to hold employees accountable when they do not uphold their duty to care for those who served. The vast majority of VA employees are hardworking and dedicated to our nation’s heroes, but some bad actors are harmful to Veterans and the VA’s mission as a whole. That’s why I was proud to co-sponsor the VA Accountability First Act and vote for its passage in the House today. The bill will give Secretary Shulkin more flexibility to remove, demote, or suspend any VA employee for poor performance or misconduct, including senior managers. It would also safeguard whistleblowers from retaliation and protect employees’ due process rights. This very important legislation will bring long overdue accountability and transparency to the agency.

Kicking off my weekly video series Discuss with Gus and answering your questions on drug costs, Medicare, and bipartisanship. Send me an email via my website bilirakis.house.gov and your question could be featured next week!  #DiscussWithGus
This morning, President Trump spoke to House Republicans in support of the American Health Care Act #AHCA

Opioid abuse in Florida and across the nation has taken a toll on our families and our communities. At a congressional hearing today, I had the opportunity to question officials on the growing public threat of fentanyl, a synthetic opioid that is 50 times more potent than heroin and 100 times more potent than morphine. In Florida, fentanyl-related deaths increased by over 100% in recent years. While most people know about the risk of opioids like morphine and heroin, I discussed the need to raise awareness of fentanyl and give local communities the tools they need to tackle the crisis and save lives.

During a committee hearing today I had the chance to speak about the OPEN Act, my bill to open the door for hundreds of new treatments for rare diseases. 30 million Americans are affected by 7,000 rare diseases, and yet 95% of those diseases have no approved medication. Rare diseases are not a rare problem, and we must act now to get patients the treatments and cures they need.

Flooding and high flood insurance premiums are major issues for our communities in Florida’s 12th District. Today I joined my friends in the Florida delegation for a bipartisan meeting on the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP). We discussed my bill, the Flood Insurance Integrity Act, to ensure that NFIP’s maps are regularly and transparently updated so Floridians actually pay an accurate amount for their flood insurance. I look forward to working together on this legislation and more to strengthen NFIP for our state.
On this week’s Discuss with Gus: Meals on Wheels, compensating Veterans fairly, and expanding choices for patients. Please keep your questions and feedback coming!

I’m thrilled we took a positive step forward today to turn the Ridge Road extension project into a reality, and I thank Governor Scott for his efforts to help get this done for the people of Pasco County. After nearly 20 years of regulatory roadblocks, local residents deserve an effective evacuation route in case of a disaster. I’m hopeful the Trump Administration will help prioritize the completion of this critical public safety project.
Enjoyed answering your calls today on the American Health Care Act. I hope you'll continue to stay in touch on the issues that matter to you!

My main concern has been, and will continue to be, making sure my constituents have access to the best possible health care. Our efforts do not stop today to ensure our nation’s health care system is stronger, more affordable, and truly patient-centered. That is my goal, and I will keep working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to accomplish it.
Happy Greek Independence Day to my fellow Greek-Americans!

7,000 rare diseases, 30 million Americans affected, but only 500 approved treatments. We can improve those numbers and save lives with the OPEN Act, my bill to incentivize drug makers to enter rare disease markets.

Over 30 #AIPAC members from Florida stopped by my office this afternoon for a fantastic meeting on reinforcing the U.S.-Israel relationship. We must continue to stand by our close ally and only democratic state in the Middle East, and ensure she has the tools to remain safe and secure in a hostile neighborhood.

Our Veterans have sacrificed so much on behalf of our country, they deserve access to high quality health care, and that includes dental care. My bill, the VET CARE Act, will get the ball rolling to expand access to dental care for our nation’s heroes by implementing a four-year pilot program. Not only is this bill good for Veterans’ dental health, it could also help alleviate chronic conditions and result in lower overall health care costs for the VA.

Great meeting with Dr. Michael Diaz with Florida Cancer Specialists who shared his insight on making health care accessible and affordable, especially for those battling cancer. Thank you, Dr. Diaz, for being a strong advocate for patients and their families across Florida.

For too long, the VA has managed to get by with a culture of mediocrity. My legislation, the VA GORDIAN KNOT Act, will help untangle some of the agency’s core problems: lack of accountability and manipulation of key data. In order to help the VA achieve its mission to care for Veterans, we need accurate, transparent data to properly address its shortcomings and enhance its successes. I believe this is absolutely necessary when it comes to reforming the agency tasked with serving our true American heroes.

Today marks the first ever official National Vietnam War Veterans Day. On this day 44 years ago, the last combat troops withdrew from Vietnam. Now, and on every March 29th going forward, we pause to honor this generation of Veterans for their sacrifice and service to our nation.

Proud to join today’s #SubCommTech hearing focused on modernizing 911 emergency systems nationwide to work with our next generation technologies. If you see a crime or emergency occurring in real time on social media, how can you report it? How can we ensure blind, deaf, and disabled individuals can easily and reliably call 911? We all have smartphones in our pockets capable of voice, text, video, and data services that could redefine 911 calls and how we communicate with first responders.

The opioid epidemic is not only a national crisis, it affects families and communities right here at home in Florida’s 12th District. I’ve worked on bipartisan legislation, the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act & the 21st Century Cures Act, to help fight this crisis but there is much more to be done. We need to work closely with local law enforcement, doctors, addiction treatment specialists, and those impacted by addiction in an all-hands-on-deck effort.  I’m thrilled the President is leading the charge on this critical issue, and I look forward to working with him to help save lives and prevent addiction.

I encourage all high school artists from my district in Pasco, Pinellas, and Hillsborough counties to enter their best work for the 2017 Congressional Art Competition. The competition is a fantastic opportunity to celebrate the creative talents of Florida’s 12th District. I look forward welcoming one lucky winner to the nation’s capital to be recognized among the best student artists in the country. Good luck to all our local young artists! Visit my website for submission details.
On this week’s #DiscussWithGus: NIH funding, President Trump’s picture in VA hospitals, and tax reform.

The VA has been known to yield less than truthful information when it comes to collecting and reporting data about patient care, wait-times, and employee hiring and firing practices. This behavior is an erosion of public trust, a disservice to our nation’s Veterans, and makes it difficult to properly address the VA’s shortcomings and enhance its successes. My bill, the VA GORDIAN KNOT Act, requires the VA to standardize its data collecting and reporting mechanisms, and increases oversight of the integrity and accuracy of the information. This is critical to reforming the VA and assisting in its mission to care for our true American heroes.

Captain Joe Simms, Colonel Frank Amodeo, and Technical Sergeant Brittany Bennett of the 927th Air Refueling Wing at MacDill AFB came by my office today to discuss additional KC-135s that are slated to arrive at MacDill and the potential for 12 more in the near future, as well as how we are supporting the coalition efforts in Afghanistan and in support of Operation Inherent Resolve. I’m grateful for their service to our country.
Thank you to Pinellas County Commissioners Janet Long, Pat Gerard, & Pinellas Suncoast Transit Authority CEO Brad Miller for bringing the voices of our local community to DC.

Productive meeting today with the Jacksonville U.S. Army Corps of Engineers regarding the Ridge Road extension project in Pasco County, and dredging the Anclote River to enhance commerce in Tarpon Springs.

The risk of suicide is 21% higher for Veterans than for non-Veterans, and on average 20 Veterans each day take their own lives. The Veterans Crisis Line is a critical tool for the VA to help those struggling with depression or suicidal thoughts, but recent investigations have found that some calls are met with busy phone lines, long wait times, or a Veteran is rerouted to backup call centers. I questioned VA officials today about the action plan to fix these serious problems.  This is a matter of life and death. The stakes are too high for even one call to go unanswered.

Today with my strong support the House passed S. 544, bipartisan legislation to continue the Veterans Choice Program beyond its expiration date. The bill will ensure Veterans continue receiving care under the program, and allow Congress to further push for reforms and improvements.

Proud to receive the National Down Syndrome Society’s Champion of Change award for my work on the Congenital Heart Futures Act, but the real winner is my friend Abigail the Advocate from Florida. Together, we can promote better treatments for congenital heart defects, and empower those living with Down Syndrome to live full, healthy, independent lives.
DAV does incredible work on behalf of our nation’s heroes. I will keep fighting to ensure every Veteran receives the care they have earned and deserve.
Congrats to Richard Krempler of Hudson, oldest FDNY retiree in America at 103 years young!

The United States has taken decisive action in response to the heinous chemical attack on innocent Syrians by the Assad regime. President Trump has sent a clear message to the international community – our nation will no longer bow to inaction and follow, we will once again stand for justice and lead. I salute the men and women of the U.S. Armed Forces who bravely and expertly carried out this mission.
On this week’s #DiscussWithGus: Internet privacy, the House investigation into Russia, and protecting VA whistleblowers.
Congratulations to Justice Neil Gorsuch on his confirmation to the Supreme Court. I know he will serve the Court and the American people thoughtfully, responsibly, and with the utmost respect.

Do you know an outstanding educator in Florida’s 12th District? Nominate them for my annual Teacher of the Year awards. While there are some worthy provisions within the fiscal year 2017 spending bill, I could not in good conscience support a spending plan that buries future generations in an additional $249 billion of debt. My commitment to the positive aspects of the bill, like strengthening our military, fighting the opioid crisis, and supporting medical research, has not wavered. But we must work in a fiscally responsible manner. Our country faces an unsustainable national debt, and I believe the bill does not do enough to rein in spending or limit the size of government. I will continue to fight for common sense reforms in the best interest of the people of Florida’s 12th District.

With the House passage of the American Health Care Act, we are moving forward with a health care system that lowers costs and increases choices. Like many Americans, I live with a pre-existing condition, as do many of my family members and loved ones. I would not have voted for the bill if I thought protections for those with pre-existing conditions were in jeopardy, as I promised my constituents during three town hall meetings. Today’s vote is the beginning of health care reform, not the be-all-end-all, and we cannot allow the perfect to be the enemy of the good. I look forward to continuing work to ensure health care is affordable and accessible for all.

In our country, lawmakers are not above the law. Moments before voting for the American Health Care Act, we passed legislation – with my full support – to ensure Members of Congress and staff are not exempt from it. Elected officials and the American people should have the same health care. Period.

With the House’s recent passage of the Veterans Appeals Improvement and Modernization Act, the VA Scheduling Accountability Act, and several other bills, we’ve made good progress to tackle some of the biggest challenges at the VA. At today’s subcommittee hearing on the 2018 budget for the Veterans Health Administration, I reiterated the need for an increased focus on evidence-based alternative treatments for Veterans.  Alternative therapies like service dog therapy, sports therapy, and others, mean our Veterans are empowered with more options to find the care that works best for them. Our Veterans deserve more than a one-size-fits-all approach to their health care, and with my bill the COVER Act, along with the Administration’s efforts, we can make alternative therapies more accessible.

When I tour Tampa Bay businesses and manufacturers, I often hear about the need for more highly-skilled workers. Florida is home to many great community colleges, vocational schools, and career centers that can help prepare folks for good-paying, in-demand jobs. Today’s legislation strengthens and reauthorizes the Perkins Act to provide state and local resources for workforce education to help Americans gain the skills they need for the 21st century job market.

Today is a significant day for our nation’s true heroes – our Veterans and their families. The Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act has been signed into law. We have seen scandal after scandal come out of the VA, and today we turn to a new chapter. This legislation puts meaningful reforms in place to ensure VA employees are fulfilling their duty to serve Veterans.   If a VA employee is involved in misconduct, they should be demoted, suspended, or fired. Certainly not promoted or given a bonus. If a VA employee sees misconduct and wants to report it, they should not fear retaliation. This legislation is common-sense, and strongly bipartisan. I am proud of the work done with my colleagues on the House VA Committee under the leadership of Chairman Roe, and I stand with our President committed to upholding our country’s promise to Veterans.

This will help Veterans receive their GI Bill benefits in a more timely and efficient manner. The challenges our nation’s heroes face do not end on the battlefield. We must ensure they have the support and resources they need to thrive in the transition back to civilian life.

This morning, I joined my fellow House VA Committee members, White House officials, and HHS and CDC officials for a great roundtable discussion on tackling the opioid crisis among Veterans. Through my bills, the COVER Act and the PROMISE Act, both now signed into law, I’ve worked closely to prevent the overprescribing of opioids at the VA and to promote alternative treatments for Veterans. From service dogs, to sports therapy, hyperbaric oxygen therapy, and more, Veterans need a broad range of options to take care of their invisible and physical wounds.

Last week, HHS announced the largest health care fraud takedown in history, spanning over 400 defendants and about $1.3 billion in losses. 80 of those cases were charged in Florida. Not only is fraud and abuse in Medicare an affront to hardworking taxpayers, it hurts the millions of seniors who rely on the program. That’s why I recently introduced the bipartisan Medicare Civil and Criminal Penalties Update Act to strengthen the fines against fraudsters. Most of these fines have not been updated in 20 years. We must crack down on fraud and abuse to ensure the Medicare program is strong for today’s and tomorrow’s beneficiaries.

September is Childhood Cancer Awareness month.  Each year, more than 15,700 children in the United States are diagnosed with cancer.  Statistically, 12% of those children will not survive. This new law will have a positive impact on the lives of children suffering with cancer and I look forward to its implementation.

Now that all 3 counties in District 12 qualify for FEMA’s Individual Assistance Program, my office has been getting inquiries about what that entails. Please see the fact sheet below outlining program information:    https://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/1461689021638-cfcfd7f6c263635802fa7a76a19e00ea/FS001_What_is_Individual_Assistance_508.pdf  You can begin your application by visiting www.disasterassistance.gov or calling 1-800-621-FEMA (3362).    Some key information from FEMA’s website is listed below:  • Home/Primary Residence: We provide housing assistance     to individuals who have lost their homes as a result of an eligible disaster.  If you are a renter or homeowner you may qualify for assistance.  By law, FEMA assistance cannot duplicate the assistance you receive from your insurance company, but you may receive assistance for items not covered by insurance.   • Business: We do not offer assistance for small businesses impacted by a presidentially-declared disaster.  However, we do partner with the Small Business Administration (SBA), which offers low interest loans for business damages.   • Secondary Home: We do not offer assistance for your secondary home.  • Other Needs Assistance: We offer disaster assistance for some of your other disaster-caused expenses including, medical and dental, child care, funeral and burial, essential household items, moving and storage, vehicle, and some clean-up items. • If you lost work due to a federally declared disaster, you may qualify for Disaster Unemployment Assistance (DUA). FEMA does not administer the DUA program. Please contact your local office of your State's Unemployment Commission for further information regarding DUA benefits. • FEMA does not compensate for evacuation expenses, even if the evacuation was mandatory; however, if your home was damaged to the extent you could not return for an extended period of time, some lodging may be reimbursable.  • Food loss is not covered by FEMA's Individual and Households Program (IHP).

This week, I was proud to support passage of the Make America Secure and Prosperous Act, which provides funding for our nation's top priorities while reducing overall spending.  For the sixth consecutive year the House budget has reduced spending levels from the prior year. This is one important step in ensuring we don't burden future generations with crippling debt.  Mandatory spending for vital programs like Social Security and Medicare occur through a different process.  Additionally, military and Veterans spending already passed the House in separate legislation. Highlights of this Appropriations package include:  • $1.9 billion increase in Homeland Security funding, including $358 million for anti-terrorism initiatives and $6.1 billion for embassy security, including $5 million for an amendment I sponsored to increase Visa Security posts in the most volatile parts of the world • $500 million in continued funding for Opioid prevention, $103 million for drug courts, addiction treatment and Prescription Drug Monitoring programs and $254 million in funding for High Intensity Drug Traffic Areas  (Pasco, Pinellas and  Hillsborough counties are all members of this program) • $200 million increase in Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) funding which supports students with special needs • $1.8 billion in funding for Alzheimer's research and $12.6 million for pediatric cancer research • $1.68 billion for a border security wall along the U.S. border with Mexico and funding for 1,000 new ICE officers, 500 new border agents and state of the art technology needed to strengthen border security • $2 billion to combat human trafficking  The spending bill also: • Allocates funding to sustain the Section 8 voucher program for those at risk of homelessness.  • Increases funding for FBI, cyber security, counter terrorism and local law enforcement programs • Protects funding for Meals on Wheels and career and technical education  • Includes several measures to remove overly burdensome regulations so small businesses can thrive • Directs the IRS not to enforce the Obamacare individual mandate penalty for 2018 • Strengthens 2nd Amendment protections • Includes several provisions to protect the sanctity of life while defunding Planned Parenthood  I look forward to working with my colleagues in the Senate to pass a comprehensive and fiscally responsible budget reflecting our nation's highest priorities.

The Small Business Administration (SBA) has released the following information about programs available to residents and businesses in Pasco, Hillsborough and Pinellas counties:   Businesses and private nonprofit organizations of any size may borrow up to $2 million to repair or replace disaster damaged or destroyed real estate, machinery and equipment, inventory, and other business assets.  Applicants may be eligible for a loan amount increase up to 20 percent of their physical damages, as verified by the SBA for mitigation purposes.  Eligible mitigation improvements may include a safe room or storm shelter to help protect property and occupants from future damage caused by a similar disaster.  For small businesses, small agricultural cooperatives, small businesses engaged in aquaculture and most private nonprofit organizations, the SBA offers Economic Injury Disaster Loans to help meet working capital needs caused by the disaster.  Economic Injury Disaster Loan assistance is available regardless of whether the business suffered any physical property damage.   Disaster loans up to $200,000 are available to homeowners to repair or replace disaster damaged or destroyed real estate.  Homeowners and renters are eligible up to $40,000 to repair or replace disaster damaged or destroyed personal property.   Interest rates are as low as 3.305 percent for businesses and 2.5 percent for nonprofit organizations, 1.75 percent for homeowners and renters with terms up to 30 years.  Loan amounts and terms are set by the SBA and are based on each applicant’s financial condition. Federal Dislocated Worker Grants are now available to Floridians.  They provide disaster relief employment in the form of temporary jobs that support storm response and recovery efforts. Disaster relief employment pertains to projects that provide food, clothing, shelter and other humanitarian assistance for disaster victims and projects that involve demolition, cleaning, repair, renovation and reconstruction of damaged structures and facilities. Individuals who qualify for disaster relief employment are people who are temporarily or permanently laid off as a consequence of the disaster, dislocated workers, and individuals who are long-term unemployed. For information regarding National Dislocated Worker Grants, visit your local CareerSource Center at http://www.careersourceflorida.com/your-local-team.   In addition to the Dislocated Worker Grants, the state is also providing the following programs to assist in recovery from Hurricane Irma:   • The Disaster Unemployment Assistance (DUA) Program provides assistance to businesses and residents whose employment or self-employment was lost or interrupted as a result of Hurricane Irma. To apply for DUA, go to www.floridajobs.org or call the Florida Disaster Unemployment Assistance Line at 1-800-385-3920.  • The Florida Small Business Emergency Bridge Loan Program provides cash flow to businesses damaged by a disaster. The short-term, interest-free loans help bridge the gap between the time damage is incurred and when a business secures other financial resources, including payment of insurance claims or longer-term Small Business Administration loans. Go to www.floridadisasterloan.org for more information.

Pinellas County residents, if you have uncollected Hurricane Irma debris on your curb (like me), please take note of this message from Pinellas County officials. Collection is on the way!  Debris removal underway in additional zones in unincorporated Pinellas Pickup this weekend in other zones to begin   •         Coordinated collection underway for debris left behind by Hurricane Irma •         Residents are asked to place debris at the county right-of-way •         Items picked up during curbside collection will include yard debris, and construction and demolition debris caused by the storm •         Residents asked to not place debris in bags  Following Hurricane Irma, coordinated debris collection continues for residents in unincorporated Pinellas County. Debris contractors began storm debris collection from county rights-of-way on Monday.   Crews are currently working on the following zones: INON03; INON05; INON06; INON07; INON08; INSW02; INSW03; INSE05; INSE06; INSE07; INSE08; INSE09. Residents are asked to place debris in sorted piles at the public (county) right-of-way for curbside collection by debris crews. If residents live on private roads or in private communities and are unable to bring the debris to the closest public right-of-way, they are asked to call Pinellas County Public Works at (727) 464-8900 for other arrangements. Residents are also advised to contact their regular garbage hauler to have it picked up. These are the specific items that can be moved to the curbside for collection:   Construction and demolition debris •         Building material including roof shingles and siding •         Drywall  •         Lumber  •         Carpet  •         Furniture  •         Plumbing Vegetation Debris •         Fallen tree branches and logs Leaves will not be accepted.  Residents are asked to take the following steps to make the debris removal process easier: •         Sort debris by type and place in separate piles •         Do not stack debris against trees, poles, fire hydrants and storm drains •         Do not place debris on sidewalks or farther back than 10-feet beyond the curb Municipal residents can contact their municipality about the availability of debris pickup in their area. Residents who are uncertain if their property is located within unincorporated Pinellas or within a municipality, should visit www.pinellascounty.org/resident/unincorporated_areas.htm. Since I have received many requests for updates on how the federal government is responding to the crisis in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands, I wanted to share the following information that was released by FEMA today:  The top priority of the federal government is continuing to provide life safety and life sustaining resources to Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. FEMA and its federal partners continue to conduct 24-hour operations, aggressively conducting search and rescue operations, bringing additional essential commodities to the islands, and restoring power at hospitals, ports, airports, and other critical facilities. While significant progress in being made in the response to Hurricane Maria, recovery for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands will be long and frustrating, and will require the help of the whole community. As access to ports, airfields, and roads continue to open, more resources will flow into hard hit areas. Power is restored to Centro Médico Hospital in San Juan and San Pablo Hospital in Bayamón, Puerto Rico. The Governor Juan F. Luis Hospital in St. Croix and the Schneider Regional Medical Center in St. Thomas are re-energized and re-established as mobile hospitals. Ports continue to open to bring in commodities, communications support, and responders to address the needs of survivors on the islands of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. In Puerto Rico, seven ports are currently open with restrictions, and eight airports are open. In the U.S. Virgin Islands, eight ports are open with restrictions, and two airports are open. Eight FEMA Urban Search & Rescue task forces are stationed and conducting operations in the Caribbean. FEMA US&R task forces have saved or assisted 516 individuals and two pets, while searching over 2,500 structures as of September 25.  FEMA encourages all residents to continue following the direction of commonwealth, territorial, and local officials. To donate or volunteer, contact the voluntary or charitable organization of your choice through the National Voluntary Agencies Active in Disasters (NVOAD). There are thousands of federal staff, including more than 600 FEMA personnel, on the ground in Puerto Rico and U.S. Virgin Islands supporting response and recovery operations from Hurricanes Maria and Irma. The federal government is working with its interagency and private sector partners to support availability, transportation and delivery of fuel, based on priorities identified by Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The federal support for fuel transportation includes air and sea logistical support by the Defense Logistics Agency (DLA), U.S. Northern Command, the U.S. Navy, and U.S. Coast Guard, in coordination with the private sector. The ports of San Juan, Fajardo, Culebra, Guayanilla, Salinas, Tallaboa, and Vieques are now open for daylight operations in Puerto Rico. The ports of Crown Bay, East Gregerie Channel, West Gregerie Channel, and Redhook Bay on St. Thomas, the ports of Krause Lagoon, Limetree Bay, and Frederiksted on St. Croix, and the port of Cruz Bay on St. John are open with restrictions. FEMA, working in coordination with federal partners, provided has provided more than 1.5 million meals, 1.1 million liters of water, nearly 300 infant and toddler kits, and nearly 12,000 emergency roofing kits to the U.S. Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico since Hurricane Maria’s landfall. Mobile Emergency Response Support (MERS) communications assets and personnel continue to support FEMA Incident Management Assistance Team (IMAT), Urban Search and Rescue (US&R), National Disaster Medical System (NDMS), and other federal teams in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. An additional MERS team is scheduled to arrive Monday. More than 100 satellite phones are en route to Puerto Rico to help address communications needs on the ground. FEMA’s National Business Emergency Operations Center (NBEOC) is facilitating private sector requests for humanitarian relief. The NBEOC continues coordination between government and private sector organizations as the community responds to Hurricanes Maria and Irma. Other federal agencies are taking the following actions:  • The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued an order on September 24 authorizing FEMA and DoD to install and operate temporary water treatment units to provide clean water in the U.S. Virgin Islands to address concerns about a lack of clean alternative water supplies. • Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the DoD conducted medical evacuations for more than 150 patients from the islands to the continental United States. Medical evacuations from the islands will continue.  • A U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) mobile communications team arrived in Puerto Rico to help improve communications across the storm-impacted area. USCG personnel continue to deliver critical FEMA relief supplies to Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. • The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) deployed debris experts to assist FEMA with debris management strategies in Puerto Rico and U.S. Virgin Islands completed a Blue Roof install on Cyril E. King Airport on St. Thomas, and completed its first residential Blue Roof install on September 23. Installations began on St. Croix Sunday, September 24. • Additionally, USACE has 86 generators on hand in Puerto Rico and St. Thomas with more than 186 additional generators en route. USACE and other supporting agencies have completed nine temporary power installs on Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands, and completed more than 100 inspections.  • Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) operations personnel are onsite in St. Thomas to evaluate, fix, and install FAA equipment, in support of air traffic control operations. • The National Guard Bureau (NGB) has thousands of Guard members on the ground in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands taking part in security and support operations. The Air National Guard is focused on transporting food, water, and communications capabilities as well as rapidly increasing airlift into affected areas.  • Customs and Border Protection airplanes and helicopters are assisting with conducting damage assessment and search and rescue missions. • More than 180 Federal Law Enforcement Officers are in San Juan and the U.S. Virgin Islands supporting search and rescue, medical teams, and other federal responders. For more information visit www.fema.gov

Based upon the questions that are coming into my office from victims of Irma, I wanted to share the following information about available federal resources:  •       You only have until November 9, 2017 to apply for FEMA or SBA aid.   •       Insurance deductibles must be met before FEMA assistance is available (SBA loans can be used to help individuals or businesses pay for their insurance deductibles) •       There is no money available through FEMA for food replacement.  All food support must come through USDA.  The primary USDA programs are the food stamp replacement program (which has already been loaded onto EBT cards) and DSNAP (which has been approved for Pinellas, Pasco and Hillsborough counties).  To date, only Pinellas County has begun offering DSNAP assistance.  The Pinellas County program starts today.  Please visit this website for more information about times and locations to apply:    https://www.dcf.state.fl.us/programs/access/fff/siteLocations.shtml •       Residents of all zip codes in Pasco, Pinellas and Hillsborough counties are eligible for FEMA and SBA assistance •       FEMA assistance will not pay for damages to fences or other structures like detached garages (assistance for these non-house structures are only available through an SBA loan or through private insurance) •       FEMA’s goal is to make primary homes habitable again. •       FEMA aid may only be used for primary residences.  SBA loans are available for landlords to fix damages to their rental homes. •       Renters who lived in a damaged home that is no longer habitable may be eligible for temporary housing/relocation expenses through FEMA •        FEMA does not cover travel or lodging  expenses for individuals who evacuated during the storm.  Temporary housing funds are available only if your home is inhabitable.    •       Tree Removal is not an eligible FEMA expense •       Costs associated with preparation for the hurricane (boarding/shuttering of windows, etc.) are not eligible for FEMA reimbursement •       SBA offers low interest loans (for up to 30 years) for businesses and individuals affected by the hurricane.  Their goal is to bring people back up to the standard they were in prior to hurricane.  •       SBA does NOT offer grants.  They only offer loans. You can go to a Business Recovery Center (BRC) for help applying for a loan. The only BRC in the Tampa Bay area is located at 13805 58th Street N, Clearwater, FL  33760.  You may also call 1-800-659-2955.  This is not the FEMA line and does not have a long wait.   •       First payments for SBA loans are not due for 12 months and businesses can apply for loans up to $2 million.   •       If you need help from FEMA, you should go to the Disaster Recovery Center (DRC).  The only DRC in the Tampa Bay area is located at 6437 Watson Rd.  Riverview, FL  33578.  FEMA knows their toll free number has a wait of several hours.  They are working on providing additional resources to reduce wait times.   •       If you are an individual denied for FEMA assistance, you SHOULD definitely apply for a SBA loan, even if you do not want a loan or do not believe you will qualify for a loan (based on your credit and/or income).  This is because individuals who are denied for SBA loans may become eligible for additional FEMA aid, called Other Needs Assistance (ONA).  ONA covers personal property, moving and storage expenses, transportation and group flood policies.  •       Businesses denied for SBA loans are not eligible for additional assistance through FEMA. •       If you are an individual or a business having other issues with FEMA or SBA, you can call my office at 727-232-2921 to speak to a caseworker.  You must complete and return a privacy form, which will enable my staff to work with FEMA or the SBA on your specific case.

There has been a great deal of false information circulating regarding the recently passed budget resolution.  First, it is important to note that the legislation was NOT an appropriations bill. It did not provide money for or take away money from any program. It simply was a broad framework to provide discretionary caps for the FY 2018 budget and set up tax reform through the reconciliation process.  Federal money is allocated through a separate funding bill. Secondly, the framework did NOT propose a reduction in spending for Medicaid or Medicare.  It proposed a non-binding reduction in the long-term projected increases for these programs. Countless independent studies have shown that reform is needed for both programs in order to ensure their long-term sustainability.  I support a bi-partisan study commission which will make recommendations about how to best achieve that goal while protecting seniors and vulnerable populations.  Despite political rhetoric, all members of Congress (Republican and Democrat) understand the importance of these programs and will work to ensure that they remain solvent for years to come.

Each day, I plan to share a piece of misinformation that is circulating about the tax reform bill along with corresponding facts.  Today's misperception:  “This raises taxes on people in the lowest income bracket, as well as people in the 33% bracket that exists today.”   That’s not true. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act reduces taxes for Americans at every income level.  This bill nearly doubles the standard deduction so more Americans in the lowest tax bracket of 12% – individuals earning up to $45,000 and married couples earning up to $90,000 – will pay zero income tax.  And because we lower the rates and increase the amount of income subject to those lower rates, Americans in the new 35% bracket – individuals earning up to $500,000 and married couples earning up to $1 million – will benefit from the significantly larger standard deduction and lower 25% rate so they will keep even more of their hard-earned money.

Today's misconception about the tax reform bill:  "This fails to provide permanent relief for families.”   Fact:  In addition to increasing the child tax credit and preserving the child and dependent care credit – which will provide permanent relief for families – the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act provides a new family credit of $300 for each parent and non-child dependent to help all families with their everyday expenses. While this new family credit expires when specific business-related tax provisions expire, we are confident future Congresses will protect this important tax relief for hardworking families.

Today's misconception about the tax reform bill:  “This will make it significantly harder for individuals with expensive illnesses and seniors with costly medical bills to afford the care they need.”   FACTS:  Approximately 6% of American taxpayers utilize the medical expenses deduction.  The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will help Americans afford the care they need by lowering tax rates across the board, roughly doubling the standard deduction, preserving the dependent care credit, and creating a new family credit that will help millions more families.  With these provisions, Americans will be able to keep more of the money they earn for expenses that arise throughout their lives – including medical bills.  Additionally, this bill is estimated to create nearly 1 million new jobs and increase paychecks by 3.1% – broadening the tax base and increasing revenues, which not only helps working seniors but also has the added benefit of ultimately improving the solvency of the Medicare Hospital Insurance Trust Fund so the Medicare program can continue to serve today’s seniors and future generations.

Today's misconception about the tax bill:  “This bill raises taxes for people with student loans. By eliminating Americans’ ability to deduct their student loan interest, the average borrower will see their taxes go up by $275 each year – just on student loan interest. And a borrower who pays the full $2,500 in interest would see their taxes go up even more – by a whopping $625.”   FACT:  This claim looks at one deduction in isolation and fails to take into account the tax relief and economic benefits that the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will provide Americans of all walks of life – including people working to pay off student loans.  In fact, while the deduction for student loan interest provides some tax relief today for some people, under this bill, people paying the interest on student loans will receive substantially more tax relief. The typical household making $59,000 each year will receive $1,182 of tax relief each year. The typical single person making $30,000 right out of college will receive over $800 of tax relief each year – more than they would receive from the existing deduction for student loan interest.  The bill consolidates the American Opportunity Tax Credit (AOTC), the Hope Scholarship Credit (HSC) and the Lifetime Learning Credit (LLC) into an enhanced AOTC. The new AOTC would provide a 100% tax credit for the first $2,000 of certain higher education expenses and a 25% tax credit for the next $2,000 of such expenses. Expenses covered include tuition, fees, and course materials. This provides a max tax credit of $2,500 for education.   The new AOTC would also be available for a fifth year of post-secondary education at half the rate as the first four years, with up to $500 of the credit being refundable.   And let’s look at the bigger picture: this bill is estimated to create nearly 1 million new jobs and increase paychecks by 3.1% – providing college graduates with career opportunities that don’t exist under today’s slow-growing economy.  It’s this job creation and wage growth, along with the specific tax relief, that will help more young people pay off their loans even faster – especially compared with the slow-growing economy Americans have been forced to settle for in recent years.

As Co-Vice Chair of the International Religious Freedom Caucus, I had the privilege of sharing my thoughts about the current status of Christians and other religious minorities in the Middle East at yesterday’s 3rd Archon International Conference on Religious Freedom. For over a decade, I have worked together in a bipartisan manner with my colleagues to condemn violations of religious freedom on behalf of the Falun Gong in China, Amadi in Pakistan, Baha’is in Iran, and so many other religious minorities worldwide. But, the single most persecuted group according to the U.S. State Department are Christians, particularly in the Middle East. Christians are suffering, dying and being displaced from their ancestral homelands at this moment. While we may not be able to eradicate every act of violence and persecution, we can surely work to extinguish international indifference.  We can give voice to those who are silenced. Martin Luther King famously said, “Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.”   Embattled Christians and other religious minorities are counting on us to come to their defense. They cannot afford to wait any longer.

Today, I introduced the Security Assessment Feasibility for Equipment Testing and Evaluation of Capabilities for our Homeland (SAFE TECH) Act.  This important legislation stems from my recent Congressional Delegation trip during which I had the opportunity to review screening procedures at major EU hubs like Amsterdam and Frankfurt for inbound travel to the United States.  Technical standards for safety and operating procedures at international airports are set by international agreements.  The standards set are generally broad; leaving vulnerabilities through inconsistencies with international partners.  My bill will address this concern.  As I have always contended, if we are not safe, then nothing else matters.  I look forward to advancing this bill through the legislative process.

In July of 1980, Israel passed a law declaring Jerusalem the united capital of Israel. Out of respect for the sovereign decision-making of Israel, the United States Congress passed The Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995, a bipartisan law requiring America to move the embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. However, the Executive Branch has ignored this legislative directive for over two decades. During my time in Congress, I have consistently supported legislation reinforcing the law and Jewish historical, religious, and cultural ties to Jerusalem. In fact, one of my first actions in Congress was to co-introduce bipartisan legislation that would require the U.S. government to take tangible steps towards recognizing Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. I applaud President Trump’s historic announcement today that he intends to honor the wishes of our strongest ally in the Middle East and implement this long-standing Congressional directive by recognizing Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and to initiate relocating the U.S. embassy there. Lasting peace can only be achieved through direct negotiations between Israelis and the Palestinians and today’s announcement does not presume an outcome to those negotiations. Rather, today’s announcement ensures Jerusalem will continue to be Israel’s capital as part of any final-status agreement between the two parties despite the concerted effort of nefarious international influence to deny Jewish links to the ancient city.

While I remain optimistic that the House and Senate will be able to reach consensus on a budget bill prior to next week’s deadline, I was proud to co-sponsor the Armed Services Always Paid (ASAP) Act  today.  This bill makes certain that if there is ever a government shutdown, military pay is treated similarly to Social Security.  This means that payments would not stop with a shutdown, and all members of the military – Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, National Guard, Coast Guard, and reserve components – would all receive their pay on time during any lapse in appropriations.  I believe this bill is essential to our national security and the very least we can do to honor our commitment to those brave men and women who are continuing to risk their lives in order to defend our freedom.  I do not want them distracted from their mission with worry that political fighting may jeopardize their family’s financial stability.  I urge my colleagues to pass this important bill as quickly as possible.

As Co-Chair of the Congressional Caucus on Hellenic Affairs and the Congressional Hellenic-Israel Alliance, I released the following statement on Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s recent comments regarding the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne during a historic head of state visit to Greece:    President Erdogan continues to test the resolve of the United States and the rest of the international community to hold his regime accountable for sowing regional chaos and discord that undermines and threatens NATO ally, Greece. Erdogan’s renewed inflammatory rhetoric and lack of respect for long-standing international agreements is cause for serious concern and does nothing to advance regional interests much less provide for stability and prosperity. The United States must remain steadfast in its support of Greece, continue to condemn flagrant acts in violation of international law, and be prepared to respond quickly and forcefully to transgressions of international law through targeted sanctions and foreign aid restrictions.

Today, I was pleased to vote in favor of the Conference Report on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. This historic tax reform will double the standard deduction, lower tax rates for all income brackets and dramatically increases the child tax credit, which will help millions of middle class Americans keep more of their hard earned money. The increase in the standard deduction will also simplify the tax system, as fewer people will itemize, saving families time and money on tax preparation.  However, the bill preserves the most important deductions that many Americans depend upon including:  student loan interest, mortgage interest, teacher supplies, medical expenses, retirement savings and $10,000 worth of state and local taxes.  Additionally, the bill includes pro-growth policies that will benefit our economy for years to come.  For example, it dramatically reduces the tax burden on small businesses, which are the job creators of America and the backbone of our economy.  The package also removes the fine levied against Americans who do not have health insurance, which is a matter of fairness.  This bill is good for our country and for average, hard-working Americans.  By supporting it, I am honoring a commitment I made to voters to deliver meaningful, immediate tax relief.

In yesterday’s Veterans Affairs Committee, we passed the VA Care in the Community Act, which reauthorizes and fixes a variety of problems in the CHOICE program. Many of these issues, such as prompt payment, have been highlighted as concerns by local Veterans.  I am pleased to share their experiences with my colleagues in Washington and to ensure the inclusion of remedies for those concerns in this legislative package. The CHOICE program is designed to ensure Veterans receive quality treatment, close to their home within a timely manner. We must assure that problems are addressed so that this goal can be achieved.  I am also pleased that an amendment I offered was incorporated prior to the bill’s favorable passage in committee. My amendment ensures that those providers who have been convicted of fraud within Medicare or Medicaid will not be allowed to participate in providing care to our nation’s heroes.  These protections are afforded to those in the private sector, so it only makes sense to provide these same assurances to our true American heroes. Today, I was proud to take another step toward ensuring continued preservation of a free and open internet through co-sponsorship of the Open Internet Preservation Act. This bill will prevent Internet Service Providers from intentionally blocking or slowing down service to websites.  Our intention is to make this a bi-partisan initiative.  We all want to ensure greater protection for consumers, keeping the internet free and open to all users without hindering innovation and competition.  While the FCC and FTC continues to monitor all Internet actors for consumer abuse, this legislation will codify consumer protection practices.
